name: Chemotherapy Encounter - Management and Complications
content:
ENCOUNTER FOR ANTINEOPLASTIC CHEMOTHERAPY:

DEFINITION:
- Healthcare encounter for administration of systemic chemotherapy
- ICD-10: Z51.11 (encounter for antineoplastic chemotherapy)
- May be inpatient or outpatient

PRE-CHEMOTHERAPY ASSESSMENT:

1. LABORATORY:
   - CBC with differential (assess for cytopenias)
   - CMP (renal/hepatic function, electrolytes)
   - LFTs (many agents hepatically metabolized)
   - Pregnancy test (if applicable)
   - Additional: Tumor markers, specific organ function tests

2. DOSE ADJUSTMENT CRITERIA:
   - Renal function (GFR/CrCl) - many agents renally cleared
   - Hepatic function (bilirubin, transaminases)
   - Performance status (ECOG 0-4, Karnofsky 0-100)
   - Prior toxicities

3. SUPPORTIVE CARE:
   - Antiemetics: 5-HT3 antagonists, NK1 antagonists, dexamethasone
   - Hydration (nephrotoxic agents: cisplatin, ifosfamide)
   - Growth factors: G-CSF if high risk neutropenia
   - Tumor lysis prophylaxis: Allopurinol, rasburicase (high tumor burden)

COMMON CHEMOTHERAPY TOXICITIES:

1. HEMATOLOGIC:
   - Myelosuppression (nadir typically 7-14 days)
   - Neutropenia: Infection risk, fever >38.3°C = emergency
   - Anemia: Fatigue, may need transfusion or ESA
   - Thrombocytopenia: Bleeding risk
   
   Management:
   - G-CSF (filgrastim, pegfilgrastim) if ANC <1000 or febrile neutropenia
   - Dose delay or reduction if severe

2. GASTROINTESTINAL:
   - Nausea/vomiting (acute <24h, delayed 24h-5days, anticipatory)
   - Mucositis/stomatitis
   - Diarrhea or constipation
   - Hepatotoxicity
   
   Emetogenic potential:
   - High (>90%): Cisplatin, AC regimen
   - Moderate (30-90%): Carboplatin, oxaliplatin, doxorubicin
   - Low (<30%): Taxanes, gemcitabine

3. RENAL:
   - Acute kidney injury (cisplatin, ifosfamide, methotrexate)
   - Hemorrhagic cystitis (cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide)
   - Electrolyte wasting (cisplatin: Mg, K)
   
   Prevention:
   - Aggressive hydration
   - Mesna (for cyclophosphamide/ifosfamide)
   - Electrolyte replacement

4. CARDIAC:
   - Cardiomyopathy (anthracyclines: doxorubicin, lifetime dose limit)
   - Arrhythmias
   - Ischemia (5-FU, capecitabine)
   
   Monitoring:
   - Baseline and periodic echocardiogram/MUGA for anthracyclines
   - Consider dexrazoxane (cardioprotective)

5. PULMONARY:
   - Pneumonitis/fibrosis (bleomycin, methotrexate)
   - Monitor O2 sat, PFTs

6. NEUROLOGIC:
   - Peripheral neuropathy (taxanes, platinum agents, vinca alkaloids)
   - Encephalopathy (ifosfamide, high-dose methotrexate)
   - Ototoxicity (cisplatin)

7. DERMATOLOGIC:
   - Alopecia (most agents, reversible)
   - Hand-foot syndrome (capecitabine, doxorubicin)
   - Extravasation injury (vesicants)

8. HYPERSENSITIVITY:
   - Infusion reactions (taxanes, platinum agents)
   - Premedicate: Dexamethasone, antihistamines

ONCOLOGIC EMERGENCIES:

1. FEBRILE NEUTROPENIA:
   - Fever ≥38.3°C (101°F) OR ≥38°C (100.4°F) for 1h + ANC <500 (or <1000 with anticipated decline)
   - EMERGENCY - Immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour
   - Empiric: Cefepime, pip-tazo, or carbapenem
   - Add vancomycin if: Hemodynamic instability, skin/soft tissue infection, positive blood culture for gram-positive
   - Antifungal if persistent fever >4-7 days

2. TUMOR LYSIS SYNDROME:
   - Massive tumor cell death → release of intracellular contents
   - Hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia
   - AKI from uric acid precipitation
   - Prevention: Allopurinol, rasburicase, aggressive hydration
   - Treatment: Electrolyte management, dialysis if refractory

3. SUPERIOR VENA CAVA SYNDROME:
   - Obstruction of SVC → facial/upper body swelling, dyspnea
   - Urgent radiation or chemotherapy

4. SPINAL CORD COMPRESSION:
   - Back pain, weakness, sensory changes, bowel/bladder dysfunction
   - MRI urgent, dexamethasone, radiation/surgery

5. HYPERCALCEMIA OF MALIGNANCY:
   - Ca >12 mg/dL: Nausea, confusion, polyuria
   - Treatment: IV fluids, bisphosphonates, calcitonin

QUALITY OF LIFE:
- Assess ECOG performance status
- Screen for distress, depression, anxiety
- Nutritional support
- Palliative care integration for symptom management
- Advance care planning

FOLLOW-UP:
- Assess for delayed toxicities
- Monitor for recurrence (imaging, tumor markers)
- Survivorship care plan
- Screen for late effects (secondary malignancies, organ dysfunction)

DOSE MODIFICATIONS:
- Hold if: ANC <1000, platelets <50K (varies by regimen), grade 3-4 non-hematologic toxicity
- Reduce 20-25% for grade 3-4 toxicity
- Discontinue if life-threatening toxicity
